titleInfo.title: PROVIDING FOR CONSIDERATION OF H.R. 5620, VA ACCOUNTABILITY FIRST AND APPEALS MODERNIZATION ACT OF 2016

extension.searchTitle: PROVIDING FOR CONSIDERATION OF H.R. 5620, VA ACCOUNTABILITY FIRST AND APPEALS MODERNIZATION ACT OF 2016; Congressional Record Vol. 162, No. 138

congVote.result: So the previous question was ordered.
congVote.dailyDigestCategory1: VA Accountability First and Appeals Modernization Act of 2016
congVote.dailyDigestSummary: The House began consideration of H.R. 5620, to amend title 38, United States Code, to provide for the removal or demotion of employees of the Department of Veterans Affairs based �D914�on performance or misconduct. Consideration is expected to resume tomorrow, September 14th.<P/>Walz amendment (No. 2 printed in H. Rept. 114-742) that seeks to strike sections 2 through 8 and section 10;<P/>Takano amendment (No. 3 printed in H. Rept. 114-742) that seeks to replace Section 3 with a new provision allowing the Secretary to suspend without pay any VA employee whose performance or misconduct threatens public health or safety, including the health and safety of veterans; and may remove a suspended employee after such investigation and review as the Secretary considers necessary, if the Secretary determines removal is in the interests of public health and safety; and<P/>Kuster amendment (No. 5 printed in H. Rept. 114-742) that seeks to replace Section 7 with S. 2921 Section 113, which contains an improved process to expedite the removal or demotion of a member of the Senior Executive Service.<P/>H. Res. 859, the rule providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 5620) was agreed to by a yea-and-nay vote of 241 yeas to 169 nays, Roll No. 499, after the previous question was ordered by a yea-and-nay vote of 237 yeas to 170 nays, Roll No. 498.

congVote.result: So the resolution was agreed to.
congVote.dailyDigestCategory1: VA Accountability First and Appeals Modernization Act of 2016
congVote.dailyDigestSummary: The House began consideration of H.R. 5620, to amend title 38, United States Code, to provide for the removal or demotion of employees of the Department of Veterans Affairs based �D914�on performance or misconduct. Consideration is expected to resume tomorrow, September 14th.<P/>Walz amendment (No. 2 printed in H. Rept. 114-742) that seeks to strike sections 2 through 8 and section 10;<P/>Takano amendment (No. 3 printed in H. Rept. 114-742) that seeks to replace Section 3 with a new provision allowing the Secretary to suspend without pay any VA employee whose performance or misconduct threatens public health or safety, including the health and safety of veterans; and may remove a suspended employee after such investigation and review as the Secretary considers necessary, if the Secretary determines removal is in the interests of public health and safety; and<P/>Kuster amendment (No. 5 printed in H. Rept. 114-742) that seeks to replace Section 7 with S. 2921 Section 113, which contains an improved process to expedite the removal or demotion of a member of the Senior Executive Service.<P/>H. Res. 859, the rule providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 5620) was agreed to by a yea-and-nay vote of 241 yeas to 169 nays, Roll No. 499, after the previous question was ordered by a yea-and-nay vote of 237 yeas to 170 nays, Roll No. 498.

titleInfo.title: PROVIDING FOR CONSIDERATION OF H.R. 3590, HALT TAX INCREASES ON THE MIDDLE CLASS AND SENIORS ACT

extension.searchTitle: PROVIDING FOR CONSIDERATION OF H.R. 3590, HALT TAX INCREASES ON THE MIDDLE CLASS AND SENIORS ACT; Congressional Record Vol. 162, No. 138

congVote.result: So the previous question was ordered.
congVote.dailyDigestCategory1: Halt Tax Increases on the Middle Class and Seniors Act
congVote.dailyDigestSummary: The House passed H.R. 3590, to amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to repeal the increase in the income threshold used in determining the deduction for medical care, by a yea-and-nay vote of 261 yeas to 147 nays, Roll No. 502.<P/>Pursuant to the Rule, the amendment in the nature of a substitute recommended by the Committee on Ways and Means now printed in the bill shall be considered as adopted.<P/>H. Res. 858, the rule providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 3590) was agreed to by a recorded vote of 239 ayes to 169 noes, Roll No. 501, after the previous question was ordered by a yea-and-nay vote of 237 yeas to 171 nays, Roll No. 500.

congVote.result: So the resolution was agreed to.
congVote.dailyDigestCategory1: Halt Tax Increases on the Middle Class and Seniors Act
congVote.dailyDigestSummary: The House passed H.R. 3590, to amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to repeal the increase in the income threshold used in determining the deduction for medical care, by a yea-and-nay vote of 261 yeas to 147 nays, Roll No. 502.<P/>Pursuant to the Rule, the amendment in the nature of a substitute recommended by the Committee on Ways and Means now printed in the bill shall be considered as adopted.<P/>H. Res. 858, the rule providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 3590) was agreed to by a recorded vote of 239 ayes to 169 noes, Roll No. 501, after the previous question was ordered by a yea-and-nay vote of 237 yeas to 171 nays, Roll No. 500.

extension.searchTitle: HALT TAX INCREASES ON THE MIDDLE CLASS AND SENIORS ACT; Congressional Record Vol. 162, No. 138

congVote.dailyDigestCategory1: Halt Tax Increases on the Middle Class and Seniors Act
Halt Tax Increases on the Middle Class and Seniors Act
congVote.dailyDigestSummary: The House passed H.R. 3590, to amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to repeal the increase in the income threshold used in determining the deduction for medical care, by a yea-and-nay vote of 261 yeas to 147 nays, Roll No. 502.

The House passed H.R. 3590, to amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to repeal the increase in the income threshold used in determining the deduction for medical care, by a yea-and-nay vote of 261 yeas to 147 nays, Roll No. 502.<P/>Pursuant to the Rule, the amendment in the nature of a substitute recommended by the Committee on Ways and Means now printed in the bill shall be considered as adopted.

congVote.result: So (two-thirds being in the affirmative) the rules were suspended and the bill, as amended, was passed.
congVote.dailyDigestCategory2: Strengthening Career and Technical Education for the 21st Century Act
congVote.dailyDigestSummary: The House agreed to suspend the rules and pass the following measures:<P/>H.R. 5587, amended, to reauthorize the Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Act of 2006, by a \2/3\ yea-and-nay vote of 405 yeas to 5 nays, Roll No. 503; and

titleInfo.title: EXPRESSING SUPPORT FOR A NEW MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING ON MILITARY ASSISTANCE TO ISRAEL

extension.searchTitle: EXPRESSING SUPPORT FOR A NEW MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING ON MILITARY ASSISTANCE TO ISRAEL; Congressional Record Vol. 162, No. 138

congVote.result: So (two-thirds being in the affirmative) the rules were suspended and the resolution was agreed to.
congVote.dailyDigestCategory2: Expressing support for the expeditious consideration and finalization of a new, robust, and long-term Memorandum of Understanding on military assistance to Israel between the United States Government and the Government of Israel
congVote.dailyDigestSummary: The House agreed to suspend the rules and agree to the following measure which was debated on Monday, September 12th:<P/>H. Res. 729, expressing support for the expeditious consideration and finalization of a new, robust, and long-term Memorandum of Understanding on military assistance to Israel between the United States Government and the Government of Israel, by a \2/3\ yea-and-nay vote of 405 yeas to 4 nays, Roll No. 504.
